metadata.titel_preek: The Trinity and the Depths of Mercy

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God, whose nature is self-giving love, pursues and redeems humanity from the 'depths' of a primordial catastrophe (sin) that humans are powerless to escape.

subject.identificatie: The Triune God (Father, Son, and Holy Spirit)
tekstueel_bewijs: God pursues us even beyond the grave
The love that persists in breaking through our resistance
He shall redeem Israel from all his iniquities

object.identificatie: Redemption and the restoration of the 'miserable offender' to the fellowship of God.

zender.identificatie: The Triune nature of God (The inmost being of God as Love).
tekstueel_bewijs: The inmost being of God is a dynamic interrelatedness that pours itself out

ontvanger.identificatie: The 'miserable offender' / The Church (Corinthians and the current congregation).
tekstueel_bewijs: the church that was breaking his heart is the one that gets the full Trinitarian blessing

helper.identificatie: Jesus Christ (Incarnation/Blood) and the Holy Spirit (Fellowship/Power).
tekstueel_bewijs: God’s love spends itself to the very last drop of the blood of the Son
the God who pursues us... with his resurrection power

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin as a 'vast primordial catastrophe' and human resistance/self-destruction.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is described not as petty rule-breaking but as a 'primordial catastrophe' and 'estrangement' that renders the human 'unable to present ourselves righteous.'

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of confession and 'fear of the Lord' as an entrance into the larger life of grace.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer/Psalmist
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The human action (confession) is a response to the realization of God's prior character (forgiveness).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God pursues us even beyond the grave
The love that persists in breaking through our resistance
voorbeelden_mens_subject: the psalmist ceases to reflect upon himself

voorbeelden: things which we ought to have done
you would do anything... to reverse the situation
knowledge that he and everyone else is a miserable offender
total inability to present ourselves righteous
God... whose nature it is to give that love

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes human 'non-pouvoir' (inability) in the face of God's 'pouvoir' (resurrection power/sovereign love).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From the 'Depths' (S2) to the realization that Forgiveness (S1) exists, leading to a 'Fear of the Lord' that is not paralysis (~S2) but wisdom.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: God takes the initiative to move the subject from S2 to S1 through the Trinitarian self-giving.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Very high; S2 is described as a 'primordial catastrophe'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon consistently places God as the active Subject of salvation and defines human participation as a passive reception of an unmerited gift.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Imagine for a moment that you are the parent...

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: It is not dependent on the worthiness of the other
The God who pursues us even beyond the grave

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Human parents/mentors are used as 'hints' or 'glimmers' of God, but the sermon explicitly states they are only small measures of the perfect love of God.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Theocentric: Paul's desperation is a reflection of God's own 'foolish' pursuit of the lost.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and 'renewed confidence' rather than a burden of performance.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic undertones; salvation is entirely God's work.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon moves logically from the nature of God (Trinity) to the nature of the human predicament (Psalm 130) and back to the resolution in God's mercy.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'fear of the Lord' and 'joyous knowledge'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: God’s love spends itself to the very last drop of the blood of the Son.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is the 'fellowship' and 'power' that sustains the believer.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is an 'impulse toward self-destruction' that humans cannot fix.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a robust example of theocentric preaching where God is the primary actant and the human is the beneficiary.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is the 'Grammar of Grace'.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Ensure the 'Secondary Program' (Ethics) is eventually addressed in subsequent sermons so 'Pouvoir' leads to 'Vouloir' in the believer.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (Sin/Death) is already sufficiently intensified.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology correctly precedes and grounds the possibility of any human response.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon masterfully avoids the trap of moralism by grounding the 'fear of the Lord' in the prior reality of divine forgiveness.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'parent' metaphor's emotional appeal, Greimasian analysis reveals that the metaphor functions to establish God as the Subject of a rescue mission.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis might focus on the historical context of Corinth; this analysis focuses on the functional roles of God and Man in the narrative engine of the text.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the 'miserable offender' label is not a psychological put-down but a necessary actantial positioning to allow God to be the sole Subject of the 'Redeem' verb.

appendices.notities: The sermon follows Fleming Rutledge's 'Grammar of Grace' almost perfectly.
